entries: 一个{@spell detect magic}的法术在每个南瓜周围显示出一个暗淡的转化魔法光环。作为一个行动，一个角色可以刻开一个南瓜，露出里面的六份种子。任何吃了一份南瓜籽的生物都会重新获得1点生命值。如果一个生物在1小时内吃了5份以上的南瓜籽，它必须在DC12宪法救赎中成功，否则就会在{@condition poisoned}小时内受到影响。

entries.name: W2. Portico and Balcony
entries: 描述一下庄园的正门，如下所示。
石阶爬到一个门廊，门廊上有一个高达十英尺的石制阳台。藤蔓缠绕着阳台的支撑柱和摇摇欲坠的石栏杆。一楼的入口处有一扇双门，门上粗略地刻着一个巨大的野猪头。阳台上有一扇未被破坏的双开门。
一个角色可以通过成功的DC15力量（（%0%））检查爬上阳台。如果有另一个角色协助，则该检查具有优势。两组双门都没有常春藤，可以安全打开。

entries.name: W3. Downstairs Hall
entries: 这个没有装饰的大厅有一个吱吱作响、发霉的木制楼梯。

entries.name: Trapped Stairs
entries: 楼梯爬升了10英尺到（%0%）。它的上半部分已经被削弱，以至于在50磅或更重的重量下会坍塌。在坍塌的楼梯上的生物必须做一个DC15的灵巧救赎，以避免掉到楼梯下面的木刺床上。如果救赎失败，该生物会落在(1%)的木刺上，每根木刺都会造成(2%)的穿刺伤害。

entries.name: W4. Parlor
entries: 这间客厅的门已被砸得粉碎。房间里散落着破碎的家具--椅子、边桌和一个酒柜的残骸。一块发霉的圆形地毯覆盖了大部分的石板地面。

entries.name: W5. Dining Room
entries: 墙上挂满了粗制滥造的血腥画，画的是野猪追赶棍状人形动物。房间的南侧有一个壁炉，房间的东半部有一张被砸碎的木制餐桌，周围有六把破椅子。
如果角色们在去伐木者营地的路上遇到了变形的{@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP}，并让它跑掉了（见"{@area A Boar-ing Encounter|14a|x}"），小树枝就会放在壁炉架上，每个成员（包括副手）都有一个。这些是{@creature Twig Blight||twig blights}，如果它们被碰触或受到伤害，就会攻击。

entries.name: Treasure
entries: 在这些废旧的家具中，有一个变色的银烛台，价值25戈比。

entries.name: W6. Kitchen
entries: 大自然在这个厨房里肆意妄为，厨房里的家具已经完全腐烂。外面的门几年前就坏了，老鼠在通往储藏室（W7区）的门的底部咬了几个洞。

entries.name: W7. Pantry
entries: 这个房间上方的屋顶大部分已经坍塌，留下的碎片散落在地板上。鸟儿在南北两面墙上的木架子上筑起了巢。老鼠很久以前就吞噬了它们所能触及的任何东西，而其他所有的食物都已经腐烂了。

entries.name: W8. Courtyard
entries: 向玩家描述这个区域的情况如下。
石阶通向一个用石板铺成的庭院，庭院的东面有一个带柱子的拱廊。上层的七个窗户可以俯瞰院子，院子中间有一个五英尺宽的石井，里面有厚厚的藤蔓喷涌而出。
如果{@area area W18|1d8|x}的兽人还没有被处理掉，请添加以下内容。
咕噜咕噜的喘息声和吼叫声从庄园的东南角爆发出来，预示着附近有兽人存在。
懂兽人语言的角色可以偷听到兽人在计划某种攻击。

entries.name: Gulthias Tree
entries: 这口井有30英尺深，里面有一棵Gulthias树，它的根部深入地下。由于没有什么空间可以伸展，这棵树已经长成了一个畸形的扭曲木柱，其卷曲的树枝之间有狭窄的缝隙。

在井中隐藏着一些{@creature Vine Blight||vine blights}--每一个成员都有一个枯萎病，再加上一个额外的枯萎病，不包括助手（最多5个枯萎病）。黑鬼们形成一个下降的柱子，最近的一个在井口下5英尺处。通过他们的（1%），他们可以感知院子里的入侵者。然而，它们只有在自己或古尔蒂亚斯树受到伤害时，或在格兰诺克（见（%2%））命令它们这样做时，才会出现攻击。一旦瘟疫离开竖井，一个中等或较小的角色就可以爬下去，在树枝之间轻松滑过（不需要检查能力）。
古尔蒂亚斯树是一种巨大的植物，汁液为血。它有15点攻击力，250点命中率，易受火灾伤害，没有行动、反应或防御。像普通的树一样，它是不动的。然而，除非它被完全连根拔起，否则即使它的命中率降至0，它也会从根部重新生长，每24小时恢复1个命中率。
在任何一个月亮是血红色的夜晚，古尔赛亚斯树可以产生（%0%）（%1%）、（%2%）（%3%）或（%4%）（%5%）。这些瘟疫从树上分裂出来，从井里爬出来，准备为格兰诺克效劳。

entries.name: Sounding the Alarm
entries: 院子里的任何响声都会惊动（%0%）和（%1%）的生物。为这些生物和井里的藤蔓枯萎症的人掷出主动权，并让他们做出如下反应。

items: 格兰诺克和{@area area W10|1c6|x}的树枝虫立即进行调查。在他们的第一个回合，他们进入院子，这时格兰诺克命令藤条虫从井里出来。然后，格兰诺克和树枝虫使用他们的行动来攻击他们最近的敌人。
在{@area area W18|1d8|x}的兽人利用他们的第一个回合下降到W9区域。他们在第二回合闯入门内并加入战斗。

entries.name: W9. Apprentices' Room
entries: 向玩家描述这个区域的情况如下。
这个房间曾经是一个集寝室、厨房和餐厅于一体的房间。四张床沿南墙而立，中间有百叶窗和床头柜。靠西墙有四个衣柜和一个摆满了普通餐具的柜子。四把椅子围绕着东北角的一张小餐桌，一张散落着锅和炊具的木架桌站在一个发黑的壁炉旁。所有的家具都是由木头制成的。
房间西南角的天花板已经坍塌，下面的区域充满了碎片，留下一个锯齿状的洞，透过这个洞可以看到上面的房间。
建造这座宅邸的巫师有四个学徒。当魔法师显然不会回来时，学徒们掠夺了图书馆（（%0%）），并带着他们的个人物品逃走了。
这个区域的任何响声都会提醒兽人进来（%0%）。在他们的第一个回合，他们从天花板上的洞里掉下来。在接下来的回合中，他们会进行攻击。
冒险者可以把高大的家具移到洞口下面，然后爬上去，到达W18区域，而不需要进行能力检查。

entries.name: W10. Wizard's Laboratory
entries: 这个房间东侧的门被砸开了，但院子里的任何光线都不足以照亮这个房间。有{@sense darkvision}或光源的角色看到以下情况。
曾经是某种实验室的地方成了废墟，其家具被打碎，堆在墙上。在房间的中央，用泥巴画在地板上的是一个10英尺宽的符号，描绘了三个闪电的尖端。
任何通过DC15智力({@skill Religion})检查成功的角色都能认出这个符号是邪恶的风暴之神塔洛斯的符号。拥有暴风雨领域的牧师会自动检查成功。
如果人物设法走到这一步而不惊动格兰诺克，他们就会抓到他在举行仪式。
在闪电汇聚的地方，一个身穿皮甲的半兽人在吞食一只死去的负鼠的内脏时表演了一段阴森的舞蹈。站在半兽人周围的是几个小树枝人。

半兽人格兰诺克是一个{@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP}。在他的指挥下，党内的每个角色都有一些{@creature Twig Blight||twig blights}--3个污点，不包括小弟。观察格兰诺克而不惊动或打断他的角色可以通过成功的DC15智力（（%2%））检查来确定他正在进行仪式。格兰诺克希望塔洛斯能回应他的祈祷，并将破坏力降到猎鹰山庄。任何人物的干扰都会破坏仪式，并引起格兰诺克的愤怒。

entries.name: Map
entries: 格兰诺克在一个皮革挎包被撕掉的盖子上涂了一张地图。它显示了永冬森林，并标明了（%0%）的位置。

entries.name: W11. Library
entries: 这个区域延伸到房子的两层。向玩家们描述一下吧。
这个房间有一个十英尺高的木制阳台，构成了它的上层，通过一个木制的螺旋形楼梯弯弯曲曲地到达石板地面。高大而空旷的书柜排列在墙上，它们的书架大多是弯曲和破损的。在下层，两根柱子的东边，有四张旧书桌，后面放着椅子。一些发霉的书散落一地。

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: 阳台上的一个书柜隐藏着一个进入W12区的秘密门。拽住书柜，书柜和暗门就会摇晃着打开。

entries.name: Treasure
entries: 在这里发现的书是用精灵语写的古老文本，描述了久违的精灵王国和文明。它们被损坏得太厉害了，没有任何价值。此外，有一张桌子的一条后腿下塞着一本小书，以便将其放平。这本书的标题是（%0%），它的书页被剪掉了，隐藏着一个小皮包，里面有（%1%）。如果角色们找到了这个包并认出了灰尘，就给玩家{@item Dust of Disappearance}的卡片，或者他们可以在{@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}中参考。

entries.name: W12. Master Bedroom
entries: 一张四柱床矗立在靠西墙的两个百叶窗之间。其他家具包括靠北墙的书桌和椅子以及靠东墙的一个空衣柜。南墙的壁炉上有一个雕刻精美的壁炉架。

entries.name: Treasure
entries: 一个{@spell detect magic}的咒语揭示了一个从壁炉壁炉中散发出来的魔法光环。任何人物在搜索它并在DC10智慧（（%1%））检查中成功后，都会发现壁炉架实际上是一个盖子，隐藏着一个长长的、隐蔽的隔间。建造这座庄园的巫师把她的（%2%）藏在这里。如果角色获得并确认了法杖，请给玩家（%%3%）卡，或者他们可以在（%%4%）中参考。

entries.name: W13. Magic Item Vault
entries: 这个房间在它的暗门后面被封存了多年。当人物打开暗门时，请描述房间的特征如下。
挂在远处墙上的一个钩子上的是一件漂亮的斗篷，当门打开时，斗篷轻轻地飘动。靠北墙的地方放着一个有小爪子的木箱。
这个箱子重达30磅，被魔法锁定。一个{@spell knock}的法术可以解锁，或者箱子可以被砸开。它是一个小型物体，AC为15，命中率为20，对毒药和精神伤害免疫。

entries.name: Treasure
entries: 挂在钩子上的衣服是一件（%0%），箱子里有一个用黑布包裹的（%1%）。如果角色获得并识别了这些魔法物品，请给玩家{@item Cloak of Billowing|XGE}和{@item Immovable Rod}的卡片，或者他们可以在{@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}中参考。

entries.name: W14. Upstairs Hall
entries: 向玩家描述这个区域的情况如下。
这个L形大厅的墙壁上挂着紧闭的门和百叶窗。在它们之间有曾经挂过装饰品的钩子。沿着一面墙的壁炉，上面安装着一个巨大的昆虫头像。自然光从大厅东端的屋顶上的一个洞中进入。坍塌的屋顶下的地板上散落着碎石。
通往楼下的木楼梯被困住了（见（%0%））。
安装在壁炉上方的头像是一个{@creature ankheg}(见{@adventure Creatures|DIP|16}章节中的"{@area Ankheg|208|x} "图示)。
通往（%0%）的走廊是黑暗的。(这里的椽子上挂着(1%)--每个党员有3个搅屎棍，不包括小弟（最多12个搅屎棍）。饥饿的海蜇会攻击任何进入这个区域的温血动物。

entries.name: W15. Bathroom
entries: 这个房间有一个圆锥形的屋顶，北面有一扇敞开的窗户，常春藤穿过窗户生长在里面。一个带爪子的铸铁浴缸矗立在房间中央。浴缸旁边是一个生锈的铁水泵，它仍然在工作，从房子下面的温泉中汲水。

entries.name: W16. Slanted Rooftop
entries: 这个木质棚顶的部分已经坍塌到（%0%），留下了缺口。最西边的15英尺见方的屋顶如果有50磅或更多的重量放在上面就会坍塌。当屋顶坍塌时，任何站在这段屋顶上的生物都必须在DC10的灵巧救赎中成功，否则就会掉入下面的W7区域，受到3（%1%）的重击伤害。

entries.name: W17. Upper Arcade
entries: 这条走廊由两扇双门和四扇敞开的窗户围成。角色可以很容易地避开从东边的窗户里长出来的常春藤。如果W18区的兽人还没有被打发走，角色可以通过南面的双扇门听到他们喧闹的谈话。

entries.name: W18. Guest Room
entries: 这个房间已经被与格兰诺克结盟的敌对者（%0%）占领。这里有四个兽人，加上党内每个角色都有一个额外的兽人，不包括副手。兽人正在磨练他们的武器，准备对（1%）进行攻击。兽人破坏了这个房间曾经的精美家具，没有留下任何有价值的东西。地板西南角有一个洞，通向下面的（%2%）。

entries.name: Leaving the Manse
entries: 当人物完成对庄园的探索后，他们在离开时受到了攻击。攻击力量包括{@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos}和{@creature Boar||boars}在{@area area W1|1b4|x}中的任何一个之前没有被杀死或被迫逃离的人。此外，{@creature Needle Blight||needle blights}从树林中涌现出来加入战斗--党内每个角色都有两只枯萎虫，不包括小弟。

entries.name: Counterattack!
entries: 在人物攻击庄园的第二天，永夜森林上空乌云密布，{@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos}对{@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6}发动了反击。{@creature Gorthok the Thunder Boar|DIP}击穿了小屋的栅栏，让20个{@creature Orc||orcs}冲进了小屋。
如果小屋被袭击时人物不在现场，猎鹰和他的仆人就会骑着猎鹰的马逃走，并赶往范达林，将小屋交给兽人。

data.name: Ending the Adventure
entries: 冒险可以以几种方式中的一种结束。理想情况下，它以打败白龙Cryovain、完成所有Phandalin任务或两者兼而有之而结束。到那时，角色们应该是6级了。在宣布冒险结束之前，给玩家们一个机会来收尾。例如，角色们可能需要回到（%0%）去领取一个未完成的奖励，或者通知镇民，龙已经被解决了。有了这样的好消息，镇长（%1%）可能会计划为英雄们举办一场宴会。接下来会发生什么就看你了。
如果最坏的情况发生了，人物死了，他们的冒险也就结束了。你可以让玩家卷起新的角色，继续他们上一个角色的工作，或者你也可以用新的角色重新开始，按照你认为合适的方式调整任务，让那些可能熟悉的玩家感到惊讶。
你也可以通过发明新的任务和新的地点来扩展这个冒险。另一个名为{@i D&D Starter Set}的介绍性产品包含一个名为{@adventure Lost Mine of Phandelver|LMoP}的冒险，它与这个冒险发生在同一地区，为1到5级的角色设计。你可以把那个冒险的地点添加到这个冒险中，让你的玩家和他们的角色有更多的地方可以探索。
一旦你用完了这个冒险所提供的所有内容，你可以为不同的玩家再次运行它，或者你可以找到一个冒险，让角色超过6级。下面的 "下一步怎么办？"部分提供了一些建议。

entries.name: Where Next?
entries: 如果你的玩家想把他们的角色提升到6级以上，他们就需要{@book Player's Handbook|PHB}来做到这一点。

If you plan to run more D&D for your players, you'll also need the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}, the {@book Monster Manual|MM}, and new adventures. Many DMs like to create their own adventures. Others prefer to run published adventures like this one. You'll find fun, inexpensive adventures for characters of all levels and groups of all sizes in the DMs Guild ({@link www.dmsguild.com|https://www.dmsguild.com}). Wizards of the Coast also publishes hardcover books that contain stand-alone adventures that can entertain you and your players for months. You can run these adventures as written, or you can do what many experienced DMs do: use the parts you like, ignore the rest, and add a few surprises of your own. Here are brief descriptions of some of these published adventures, to help you choose the one that's right for you.

{@adventure Curse of Strahd|CoS} {@b (for levels 1–10)}. Eerie mist engulfs the adventurers and transports them to Barovia, a land of Gothic horror ruled by the vampire Strahd von Zarovich. To escape Barovia, the characters must confront and defeat the vampire in his terrifying castle.

{@adventure Hoard of the Dragon Queen|HotDQ} {@b (for levels 1–7)} and {@adventure The Rise of Tiamat|RoT} {@b (for levels 8–15)}. Tiamat, the Queen of Evil Dragons, is trapped in the Nine Hells—but not for long if her servants amass enough treasure to buy her freedom. This adventure is split across two books.

{@adventure Out of the Abyss|OotA} {@b (for levels 1–15)}. Trapped in a vast subterranean labyrinth called the Underdark, the characters must fight monsters and forge alliances to survive. Along the way, they encounter wandering demons that are spreading madness wherever they go.

{@adventure Princes of the Apocalypse|PotA} {@b (for levels 1–15)}. East of Phandalin lies the peaceful Dessarin Valley, where four evil elemental cults have gained a foothold. To protect the valley and its settlements, the characters must root out and destroy these cults and their leaders.

{@adventure Storm King's Thunder|SKT} {@b (for levels 1–10)}. Evil giants seek to conquer the Sword Coast. If the characters can find Hekaton the storm giant king, he can put an end to the giants' rampage, but a secret enemy stands in their way.

{@adventure Tomb of Annihilation|ToA} {@b (for levels 1–11)}. A trap-ridden tomb holds a device that is capturing and devouring the souls of the dead. To save these poor souls, the characters must cross a vast jungle, descend into the tomb, and defeat the horrors within.

{@adventure Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage|WDMM} {@b (for levels 5–20)}. Beneath the city of Waterdeep lies the dungeon of Undermountain, ruled by the mad wizard Halaster Blackcloak. Many heroes enter, but few escape!

data.name: Creatures
entries: This section contains stat blocks and descriptions for the creatures that appear in {@i Dragon of Icespire Peak}.

entries.name: Creature Stat Blocks
entries: A creature's stat block provides the essential information that you, as the DM, need to run the creature.

entries.name: Size
entries: The Size Categories table shows how much space a creature of a particular size controls in combat. This space is not a measure of the creature's physical dimensions. For example, a typical Medium creature isn't 5 feet wide, but it controls a space that wide. If a Medium orc stands in a 5-foot-wide doorway, other creatures can't get through unless the orc lets them.

entries.name: Squeezing into a Smaller Space
entries: A creature can squeeze through a space large enough for a creature one size smaller than itself. When squeezing through such a space, the creature's speed is halved. While squeezing, a creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and Dexterity saving throws, and attack rolls against it have advantage.

entries.name: Type
entries: A creature's type speaks to its fundamental nature. The following types of creatures appear in this adventure.

items: {@b Beasts}. Nonhumanoid creatures that, like real-world animals, are a normal part of the world's ecology.
{@b Dragons}. Winged, reptilian creatures of ancient origin and tremendous power.
{@b Elementals}. Creatures comprised of one or more of the fundamental elements of air, earth, fire, and water.
{@b Giants}. Humanoid-like creatures that tower over humans and their kin.
{@b Humanoids}. Bipedal peoples of the civilized and savage world, including humans, dwarves, elves, and halflings.
{@b Monstrosities}. Frightening creatures that sometimes resemble beasts but that are often touched by magic and almost never benign.
{@b Oozes}. Gelatinous creatures that generally have no fixed shape. They are mostly subterranean.
{@b Plants}. Plant creatures, as opposed to ordinary plants, have some degree of sentience and mobility.
{@b Undead}. Once-living creatures brought to a horrifying state of undeath through the practice of necromantic magic or some unholy curse.

entries.name: Tags
entries: A creature might have one or more tags appended to its type, in parentheses. For example, a mimic has the monstrosity (shapechanger) type. These parenthetical tags provide an additional layer of categorization for certain creatures, but they have no bearing on how a creature is used in combat.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: A creature's alignment reflects its disposition. Alignment indicates whether a creature leans toward law or chaos and good or evil, or whether a creature is neutral.

entries.name: Any Alignment
entries: Some creatures, such as the veteran, can have any alignment. In other words, you choose the creature's alignment. Depending on the creature, its alignment entry might indicate a tendency or aversion toward law, chaos, good, or evil.

entries.name: Unaligned
entries: Many creatures of low intelligence have no comprehension of law or chaos, good or evil. They don't make moral or ethical choices, but rather act on instinct. These creatures are unaligned, which means they don't have an alignment.

entries.name: Armor Class
entries: A creature that wears armor or carries a shield has an AC that takes its armor, shield, and Dexterity into account. Otherwise, a creature's AC is based on its Dexterity modifier and any natural armor or supernatural resilience it might possess.
If a creature wears armor or carries a shield, the kind of armor it wears or shield it carries is noted in parentheses after its AC value.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: A creature usually dies or is destroyed when its hit points drop to 0. For more on {@book hit points|PHB|9|Hit Points}, see {@book the rulebook|PHB}.

entries.name: Speed
entries: A creature's speed tells you how far it can move on its turn. For more information on {@book speed|PHB|8|Speed}, see {@book the rulebook|PHB}.
All creatures have a walking speed; those that have no form of ground-based locomotion have a walking speed of 0 feet. Many of the creatures herein have one or more additional movement modes.

entries.name: Burrow
entries: A creature that has a burrowing speed can use all or part of its movement to move through sand, earth, mud, or ice. It can't burrow through solid rock unless it has a special trait that allows it to do so.

entries.name: Climb
entries: A creature that has a climbing speed can use all or part of its movement to move on vertical surfaces. The creature doesn't need to spend extra movement to climb.

entries.name: Fly
entries: A creature that has a flying speed can use all or part of its movement to fly. If the creature is {@condition incapacitated} or knocked {@condition prone} while flying, it falls unless it can hover.

entries.name: Swim
entries: A creature that has a swimming speed doesn't need to spend extra movement to swim.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: Every creature has six ability scores (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma) and corresponding modifiers. For more information on {@book ability scores|PHB|7|Ability Scores and Modifiers} and how they're used in play, see {@book the rulebook|PHB}.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: The Saving Throws entry is reserved for creatures that are particularly adept at resisting certain kinds of effects.

entries.name: Skills
entries: The Skills entry is reserved for creatures that are proficient in one or more skills. For example, a perceptive and stealthy creature might have higher-than-normal bonuses to Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

Skills in a creature's stat block are shown with the total modifier—the creature's ability modifier plus its proficiency bonus. If a creature's stat block says "{@skill Stealth} +6," roll a {@dice d20} and add 6 when the creature makes an ability check using {@skill Stealth}.

entries.name: Armor, Weapon, and Tool Proficiencies
entries: Assume a creature is proficient with its armor, weapons, and tools. If you swap out a creature's armor and weapons, you must decide whether the creature is proficient with its new equipment. See {@book the rulebook|PHB} for what happens when you use these items without proficiency.

entries.name: Vulnerabilities, Resistances, and Immunities
entries: Some creatures have vulnerability, resistance, or immunity to certain types of damage. Additionally, some creatures are immune to certain conditions and other game effects. These immunities are also noted here.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The Senses entry notes a creature's passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score, as well as any special senses the creature might have, such as the following senses.

entries.name: Blindsight
entries: A creature with {@sense blindsight} can perceive its surroundings without having to rely on sight, within a specific radius.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: A creature with {@sense darkvision} can see in the dark within a specific radius. The creature can see in dim light within the radius as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. The creature can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Tremorsense
entries: A creature with {@sense tremorsense|MM} can detect and pinpoint the origin of vibrations within a specific radius, provided that the creature and the source of the vibrations are in contact with the same ground or substance. {@sense Tremorsense|MM} can't be used to detect flying or incorporeal creatures. Many burrowing creatures, such as ankhegs, have this special sense.

entries.name: Languages
entries: The languages that a creature can speak are listed in alphabetical order. Sometimes a creature can understand a language but not speak it, and this is noted in the entry.

entries.name: Challenge
entries: An appropriately equipped and well-rested party of four adventurers should be able to defeat a creature that has a challenge rating equal to their level without suffering any casualties. Creatures that are significantly weaker than 1st-level characters have challenge ratings lower than 1.

entries.name: Experience Points (XP)
entries: The number of experience points a creature is worth is based on its challenge rating. Typically, XP is awarded for defeating the creature, and characters gain levels as they accumulate XP.
In {@i Dragon of Icespire Peak}, you don't need to track experience points, as characters advance in level by completing quests instead of accumulating XP.

entries.name: Traits
entries: Traits are special features of the creature that are likely to be relevant in a combat encounter.

entries.name: Actions
entries: When a creature takes its action, it can choose from the options in the "Actions" section of its stat block. {@book The rulebook|PHB} describes other actions available to all creatures.

entries.name: Melee and Ranged Attacks
entries: The most common actions that a creature will take in combat are melee and ranged attacks. These can be spell attacks or weapon attacks, where the "weapon" might be a manufactured item or a natural weapon, such as a claw.

entries.name: Hit
entries: Any damage or other effects that occur as a result of an attack hitting a target are described here. As the DM, you can take average damage or roll the damage; for this reason, both the average damage and the die expression are presented. For example, a monster might deal 4 ({@dice 1d8}) slashing damage with its longsword. That notation means you can have the monster deal 4 damage, or you can roll {@dice 1d8} to determine the damage.

entries.name: Reactions
entries: If a creature can do something unusual with its reaction, that information is contained here. Most creatures don't have special reactions, in which case this section is absent. {@book Reactions|PHB|9|Reactions} are explained in {@book the rulebook|PHB}.

entries.name: Limited Usage
entries: Some special abilities—whether they are traits, actions, or reactions—have restrictions on the number of times they can be used.

entries.name: X/Day
entries: The notation "X/Day" means a special ability can be used a certain number of times and that a creature must finish a long rest to regain expended uses.

entries.name: Recharge X–Y
entries: The notation "Recharge X–Y" means a creature can use a special ability once and that the ability then has a random chance of recharging during each subsequent round of combat. At the start of each of the creature's turns, roll a {@dice d6}. If the roll is one of the numbers in the recharge notation, the creature regains the use of that special ability. The ability also recharges when the creature finishes a short or long rest.

entries.name: Creature Descriptions
entries: The creatures that appear in the adventure are presented in this section in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Anchorite of Talos
entries: These {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|religious recluses} are granted spellcasting power by Talos, the god of storms. Their human ancestors bred with orcs, and now all anchorites of Talos are half-orcs.

entries.name: Ankheg
entries: An {@creature ankheg} resembles an enormous, many-legged insect that burrows underground while using its {@sense tremorsense|MM} to detect prey. When it detects movement above, it bursts from the ground and uses its mandibles to seize prey. From its maw, it secretes acidic enzymes that help dissolve a victim for easy swallowing. It can squirt these enzymes to take down foes beyond its reach.

entries.name: Banshee
entries: A {@creature banshee} is the hateful spirit of a once-beautiful female elf. It appears as a luminous, wispy form that vaguely recalls its mortal features. A banshee's face is wreathed in a wild tangle of hair, and its body is clad in wispy rags that flutter and stream around it.
A banshee is forever bound to the place of its demise. It abhors mirrors, for it can't bear to see the horror of its undead existence.

entries.name: Blights
entries: Blights are malevolent, supernatural plant monsters that try to spread evil wherever they can. Three kinds of blights are described here.

entries.name: Needle Blight
entries: In the shadows of a forest, {@creature needle blight||needle blights} might be mistaken at a distance for shuffling, hunched humanoids. Up close, these creatures reveal themselves as horrid plants whose conifer-like needles grow across their bodies in quivering clumps. A needle blight lashes out with these needles or launches them as an aerial assault that can punch through armor and flesh.

entries.name: Twig Blight
entries: {@creature Twig blight||Twig blights} can root in soil and resemble woody shrubs while rooted. When it pulls its roots free of the ground to move, a twig blight's branches twist together to form a humanoid-looking body with a head and limbs. Given how dry they are, twig blights are particularly susceptible to fire.

entries.name: Vine Blights
entries: Appearing as masses of slithering creepers, {@creature vine blight||vine blights} can animate the plants around them, using these plants to entangle foes. Vine blights are the only blights capable of speech, which they use to taunt victims or bargain with powerful foes.

entries.name: Boar
entries: {@creature Boar||Boars} are dim-witted omnivores that avoid combat unless they are particularly hungry or ornery. A boar attacks by charging and goring enemies with its tusks.

entries.name: Carrion Crawler
entries: {@creature Carrion crawler||Carrion crawlers} are large subterranean predators and scavengers that scour putrid flesh from carcasses and gobble the slimy bones that remain. They aggressively attack any creature that trespasses on their territory or disturbs their feasting.

entries.name: Centaur
entries: Reclusive wanderers and omen-readers of the wild, {@creature centaur||centaurs} avoid conflict but fight fiercely when pressed. They roam the vast wilderness, keeping far from borders, laws, and the company of other creatures.

entries.name: Commoner
entries: {@creature Commoner||Commoners} include peasants, serfs, servants, pilgrims, merchants, artisans, and hermits.

entries.name: Cow
entries: Use the {@creature cow|VGM} stat block to represent common varieties of cattle, including oxen.

entries.name: Don-Jon Raskin
entries: Adventurers who undertake the {@area Mountain's Toe Quest|03b|x} meet {@creature Don-Jon Raskin|DIP}, a fearless troubleshooter who has experienced more than his fair share of adventures.

entries.name: Falcon the Hunter
entries: Adventurers encounter {@creature Falcon the Hunter|DIP} if they visit his {@adventure hunting lodge|DIP|6} in Neverwinter Wood.

entries.name: Ghoul
entries: {@creature Ghoul||Ghouls} roam in packs, driven by an insatiable hunger for humanoid flesh. They thrive in places rank with decay and death. If they can't gorge on dead flesh and decomposing organs, they pursue living creatures and attempt to make corpses of them.

entries.name: Giant Crab
entries: A {@creature giant crab} weighs as much as an average adult human. Protected by a thick shell, it attacks with its pincer claws.

entries.name: Giant Rat
entries: {@creature Giant rat||Giant rats} roam in packs through sewers, caves, and other dank places. They are often found in the company of wererats (see page 64).

entries.name: Giant Spider
entries: To snare its prey, a {@creature giant spider} spins elaborate webs or shoots sticky strands of webbing from its abdomen. Giant spiders are most commonly found underground, making their lairs on ceilings or in dark, web-filled crevices. Such lairs are often festooned with web cocoons holding past victims.

entries.name: Gorthok the Thunder Boar
entries: {@creature Gorthok the Thunder Boar|DIP|Gorthok} is a primal nature spirit that takes the form of a boar as big as an elephant, with lightning that dances along its tusks. Gorthok serves the will of Talos, god of storms, and can be summoned during stormy weather to do the bidding of Talos's evil followers. Like its patron deity, Gorthok revels in destruction.

entries.name: Harpy
entries: A {@creature harpy} is always on the hunt for prey. Its sweet song has lured countless adventurers to their deaths, drawing them in close for the harpy to kill and then consume.

entries.name: Hunter Shark
entries: A fully grown {@creature hunter shark} is 15 to 20 feet long.

entries.name: Invisible Stalker
entries: An {@creature invisible stalker} is a remorseless creature of elemental air. It's naturally {@condition invisible}, hence its name.

entries.name: Manticore
entries: {@creature Manticore||Manticores} are fierce killers that hunt far and wide for prey. They aren't particularly bright but can converse with intelligent prey. If a manticore sees an advantage to be gained by sparing a creature's life, it does so, asking for a tribute or sacrifice equal to the loss of food.

entries.name: Mimic
entries: {@creature Mimic||Mimics} are shapeshifting predators that can alter their outward texture to resemble wood, stone, and other basic materials. They do so to assume the appearance of inanimate objects that other creatures are likely to come into contact with. A mimic in its altered form is nearly unrecognizable until it sprouts pseudopods and attacks.

entries.name: Ochre Jelly
entries: {@creature Ochre jelly||Ochre jellies} are yellowish blobs that can slip through narrow cracks in pursuit of creatures to devour. Their digestive enzymes dissolve flesh quickly but have no effect on other substances such as bone, wood, or metal.

entries.name: Ogre
entries: {@creature Ogre||Ogres} are as lazy of mind as they are strong of body. They live by raiding, scavenging, and killing for food and pleasure. The average adult specimen stands 9 to 10 feet tall and weighs close to a thousand pounds.

entries.name: Orc
entries: {@creature Orc||Orcs} are savage raiders with an unmatched lust for carnage. They worship a pantheon of evil gods, the mightiest being Gruumsh. While they regard dwarves as natural enemies, orcs hate elves above all, for the elven god Corellon Larethian half-blinded Gruumsh with a well-placed arrow to the orc god's eye. Since then, orcs have taken particular joy in slaughtering elves.

entries.name: Riding Horse
entries: A character can purchase or sell a healthy {@creature riding horse} in Phandalin for 75 gp.

entries.name: Rock Gnome Recluse
entries: {@creature Rock gnome recluse|DIP|Rock gnome recluses} are skilled in the arcane arts. They use their magical talents to create all kinds of wondrous inventions, very few of which work as intended.

entries.name: Stirge
entries: {@creature Stirge||Stirges} attach to living creatures and drain their blood. Packs of them can be a formidable threat, reattaching as quickly as their weakening prey can pluck them off.

entries.name: Veteran
entries: {@creature Veteran||Veterans} include soldiers retired from military service and warriors who never served anyone but themselves.

entries.name: Will-o'-Wisp
entries: {@creature Will-o'-wisp||Will-o'-wisps} haunt lonely places and battlefields, where they feed on fear and despair. They look like wispy, bobbing lantern lights in the distance.

entries.name: Wererat
entries: {@creature Wererat||Wererats} are cunning lycanthropes that operate much like a thieves' guild. Through its bite, a wererat can pass along the curse of lycanthropy—something it normally reserves for new gang recruits. A player character cursed with wererat lycanthropy becomes an NPC under the DM's control on nights of the full moon.

entries.name: Wererat Lycanthropy
entries: Any humanoid creature cursed with wererat lycanthropy retains its statistics except as follows:

items: The creature gains the wererat's speed in rat form, as well as the wererat's damage immunities, traits, and actions that don't involve equipment. It can't speak while in rat form.
The creature gains a Dexterity of 15 if its score isn't already higher.

The creature is proficient with the wererat's bite attack. Attack and damage rolls for its bite are based on the creature's Strength or Dexterity, whichever is higher. The save DC for the creature's bite is 8 + the creature's proficiency bonus + the creature's Constitution modifier.

entries.name: Young White Dragon
entries: {@creature Young White Dragon||White dragons} prefer cold climates. They are vicious, cruel reptiles driven by hunger and greed. Their bestial nature makes them the best hunters among dragonkind.

data.name: Sidekicks
entries: On your adventures, the DM might reveal that you've befriended a special character called a sidekick, who joins your party. This appendix presents the game statistics for sidekicks, of which there are three types:
{@b Expert}, an agile and exceedingly helpful jack of all trades
{@b Spellcaster}, a magic-user who can cast spells to harm your foes or heal you and your friends
{@b Warrior}, a martial companion who specializes in striking your foes or defending you and your allies
The DM will either tell you which type of sidekick to use or let you choose one. It's up to you and the DM to decide who controls the sidekick in play.

entries.name: Donnabella Fiasco
entries: {@i Human Spellcaster}
Donnabella is a young magic-user who wears a papier-mâché unicorn mask because it makes her feel more magical.
Use the {@creature Spellcaster|esk} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I'd rather talk to a book than most people."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "We all have a little magic in us. The trick is finding it and bringing it forth."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I want to join a prestigious wizards' academy one day. I just hope they accept unicorns!"

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I can't keep a secret to save my life—or anyone else's."

entries.name: Galandro Luna
entries: {@i Human Expert}
Galandro's most treasured possession is a fiddle that he tunes and plucks constantly.
Use the {@creature Expert|esk} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I love a good insult, even one directed at me."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I like seeing the smiles on people's faces when I perform. That plus their adoration is all that matters."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "My fiddle was gifted to me by a good friend. I cherish it above all other things."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I'll do anything to win fame and renown."

entries.name: Inverna Nightbreeze
entries: {@i Moon Elf Warrior}
Inverna has a scar on her cheek where she was grazed by an orc's javelin. She is cautious by nature and suspicious of strangers.
Use the {@creature Warrior|esk} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I choose my words very carefully. Sarcasm, I'm told, is my sharpest weapon."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "All people deserve to be treated with dignity, regardless of their station. Of course, orcs aren't people."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "Orcs are a blight on the land. For the sake of the natural and civilized worlds, I kill them on sight."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I can't admit when I'm wrong."

entries.name: Nib Addlespur
entries: {@i Lightfoot Halfling Spellcaster}
Nib is a happy-go-lucky gambler who keeps a deck of Three-Dragon Ante cards in her vest pocket. She also has a goldfinch named Lil.
Use the {@creature Spellcaster|esk} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I can't resist a sure bet or a friendly wager."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "The more complicated the scheme, the better."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I love birds and will do what I can to look after them."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "Deep water terrifies me. I would rather be swallowed by a dragon than get in a boat or go for a swim."

entries.name: Pickled Pete
entries: {@i Human Expert}
Pete likes ale and tends to function better while tipsy. At his best, he's quite the handyman and comes up with all sorts of crazy ways to get things done.
Use the {@creature Expert|esk} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "My friends know they can rely on me, no matter what."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I like coming up with new ways to do things. What problem can't be solved with a little ingenuity?"

entries.name: Bond
entries: "A full flask of wine is worth ten pockets full of gold."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "All this drinking is bad for my memory. Seriously, I can't remember my last name."

entries.name: Quinn Hightopple
entries: {@i Lightfoot Halfling Warrior}
Quinn is a happy little scrapper who likes to punch people in the groin.
Use the {@creature Warrior|esk} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "Nice set of teeth you got there. Be a shame if something bad happened to 'em."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "No challenge is too big to overcome. As Papa Bartho always says, the bigger they are, the harder they fall."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "Nothing's more important than friendship. That's why I'll never leave a friend behind."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I can't resist punching tall folk in the groin. I call it the Halfling Hello."

entries.name: Ruby Hammerwhacker
entries: {@i Shield Dwarf Warrior}
Ruby lacks the customary dwarven stoicism and greets every day with a warm smile and a renewed sense of optimism.
Use the {@creature Warrior|esk} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "Nothing can shake my optimistic attitude."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "We should all seek the betterment of ourselves. There's always room for improvement."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves"

entries.name: Flaw
entries: ""Tell me I can't do something, and I must prove you wrong."

entries.name: Shanjan Kwan
entries: {@i Human Spellcaster}
Kwan died and was raised from the dead as an infant, whereupon a tiny black glyph—the symbol of necromancy—appeared on his forehead.
Use the {@creature Spellcaster|esk} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I've cheated death once. I can do it again."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "Great beauty can hide great ugliness. The reverse is also true."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I've been searching my whole life for the answer to a simple question: Am I a god?"

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I don't like mysteries. Unraveling them keeps me up at night."

entries.name: Talon Thornwild
entries: {@i Human Expert}
Talon loves gold and adventure, and dreams of being a famous gold prospector.
Use the {@creature Expert|esk} sidekick stat block to represent them.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "Yes, I eat like a pig and have bad manners, but those are my only flaws, I swear. I'm darn near perfect otherwise."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "The low are lifted up, and the high and mighty are brought down. Change is the nature of things."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I like gold. I like its color, its texture, its majestic gleam."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "It's not stealing if I need it more than someone else."
